I only played on the free weekend during the review.
There are good and bad things with the game. The game didn't crash for me, not even once, while many complain for a lot of crash. I played with the CS1 for a 100+ hours, mostly casually, just like in this one. My config is not the best compared to the recommended requirements (the minimum should be ignored for any games tbh), the problem is mainly on the gpu.

TL;DR : You should wait for a 50% sale at least

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
[list]
[*]There are roundabouts in the game without mods, unlike in the first game.
[*]I liked the dummy version of the traffic manager. It was nice to set things in the intersections for myself, it would be better if the lane rules could be set for each lane. The ability to prohibit U-turns by default would be great, but for these cases the Traffic mod was useful.
[*]The new road upgrade/replace mode is so much better than in CS1. You don't have to upgrade it on the middle of the road, very useful in highway intersections or if you don't want to destroy your buildings when upgrading for a bigger road. Although it takes some time to get used to it, but with turning off every snapping you can move the road a little bit.
[*]The new progression system with the development points is really good, I could use the crematorium from really early on, while in the CS1 it was quite some time to unlock it.
The free region packs are good as well.
[*]The new way of the service buildings is so much better than in the CS1. They are cost more than in the pervious one for sure, but the zones are much bigger. It was always strange for me that in the CS1 you had to put down 2 schools for like 3k people, multiple police stations, etc.
[*]The upgradable buildings are great.
[*]The really basic production functionality is good. Now the produced things have an impact on your city, mainly on the cost with no need for import.
[*]The powerlines and the pipes being built-in most of the roads is great.
[*]Mid level and mixed-use housing.
[*]Topography for building is a great help, because without it sometimes is hard to tell the height differences.
[*]Parallel mode and grid tool. The grid tool would be more useful, if you could set how to divide the area up, for example 3x4 or 4x4.
[*]Continuously making the connection for the intersections, don't need to stop at each one.
[*]Asymmetric roads
[*]New happiness system, now you can see what the citizens' problem.
[*]The game looks good, with the exception of the LOD.
[/list]

[h3]Cons:[/h3]
[list]
[*]There could be more policies, policy for free public transport (manually need to set it for every line), same fee for the parking lots by default, etc. But my biggest problem with them is, that I can't set any district policy for the whole city.
[*]The LOD (level of detail) is awful, the more detailed buildings became smashed in noticeably if you zoom out, even it's not so far. This doesn't really change with higher settings either.
The optimalization is really bad, I could run the CS1 on anything back in the day. There should be no need for a 3080 for the recommended requirements. For comparison the CS1 recommended gpu was the 580, which was 5 years old at the release, not a 680 which would be the same 3 year time gap as between the 3080 and the CS2 release date. I don't know what the devs did in the past 2 years, because the region packs and all of the current DLCs are mostly the job of a graphics designer, so the devs could have plenty of time fixing it.
[*]The way how the industries working in the game is a setback compared to the previous one. The district version was better. It should be more detailed, like in the CS1 DLCs. I think it's a reasonable expectation to have some of it in the successor base game.
[*]The price, the base game should be 40 euros by default, not with the sales. I will probably buy it if it's 50% off at least.
[*]This should be an early access in this form, not a release.
[*]Traffic lights, still causing more trouble then use, just like in the CS1. The timing is the same for every lights in the intersection, even if the traffic flow most of the time is not the same for each side.
[*]Using the stop sign for anything is a nonsense, it makes the whole intersection using stop signs. In CS1 you could set the stop sings for each road in the intersection.
[/list]

I don't consider the traffic accidents and some idiot drivers a bad thing, because these things can happen irl as well, although there  could be an option to change its occurrence.

[h3]At the end:[/h3]
I would give a mid rating for the game if it was an available option on Steam. But between the yes or no, I slightly tend more to recommend it than not. However, just like I said, you should wait for a sale, with this price a 50% one at least.

This game throws DLC after DLC at you. The DLC is soulless, and provides ~$1/minute of entertainment. The graphics are nice but I do miss the previous title.... the bugs too I must mention...

Ah wait this isn't Sims 4.

Skylines 2 is the forever game. While we patiently waited for the port DLC something around 20gb of free OFFICIAL content was released via their brilliantly implemented mod manager. Factoring sales, I have paid only $50 for this game and the content just keeps rolling in. I'm not even finished playing with the content that came out months ago, hardly touched the China asset pack which is gorgeous. The DLC almost perfectly tied all that had been released together, and with the bike update just dropped, this game is perfection*. NETHERLANDS. 

I've seen complaints about performance but I get ~60fps even at 300k population, and when you sit back and consider how ludicrous the volume of simulation happening I think its acceptable if the game sneezes occasionally.. Seriously, click a random citizen, and watch them go about 10 minutes of their day. On the way to the park to walk their dog they pass 1000 other citizens, some shopping, others waiting for the bus, many with dogs of their own (there are so many puppers, I love this but cat update please, unplayable). Model railroad and Glenworld enthusiasts rejoice as we immerse into this horrifyingly immersive simulation. 


*Disclaimers
- My wrists hurt.

- This game is full of bugs, infested even. HOWEVER every single bug I've come across (and I am a risky player who absolutely ABUSES the Anarchy mod and MoveIt) is comletely fixable. This will make some players sick but I usally click continue when the game crashes and just delete whatever caused the crash and pretend nothing happened lol. I save backups every 30 minutes, and after anything finicky. I also like to keep my mods around 20-30 so that updates don't cause huge delay. The modders are fast. The mods are robust. Usually a 2 day break and all is functional. With patience you'll work through any quirk that I am aware of. I highly recommend watching some realism focused youtubers such as Infrastructurist or Cityplannerplays. They do well to cover vanilla mechanics as well as modded techniques which will make the game far more playable for a new player. 

- Bringing me into my third disclaimer. Cities Skylines is probably one of the hardest games that exist. Slight exaggeration perhaps, but that could be imposter syndrome talking. This isn't Minecraft anymore lads. The skillset is this mindmelting combination of 3D animation software, actual civil engineering and city planning, and a boatload of knot theory. I think if I switched my degree I'd have made a disturbing amount of progress. The 700 hours does not reflect the research I've done on road heirachy, intricate zoning layouts, ecological considerations, city history and flow of development, you name it. Despite this I still find myself cheesing some cities with a fat geothermal power plant exporting to the neighbours just to stop myself hovering in the red. 

At the time of writing this review the game has cost me $0.001/minute of entertainment. 
THIS DOES NOT INCLUDE ELECTRICITY LMAO.
This game is the only game that pushes my PC to 100% fan speed jet engine turbo mode. I can only imagine how thirsty the PSU is while it runs. 
Also side note, if you don't like heatstroke or exploding graphics cards live in Europe or Antarctia:)

If you think you can handle all that then have fun.

Despite all of its flaws, I‚Äôve genuinely enjoyed the time I‚Äôve spent with it. However, even after being on the market for more than two years, Cities: Skylines II still struggles to meet the expectations set for a major sequel. At launch, it felt closer to an early-access title‚Äîhampered by severe performance issues, stability problems, and a striking lack of content compared to its predecessor, Cities: Skylines 1.

A significant part of my frustration stems from how both Colossal Order and Paradox Interactive have handled the game. Colossal Order, once known for their polished and community-focused approach, delivered a sequel that appeared rushed and underdeveloped. Meanwhile, Paradox Interactive‚Äôs publishing strategy hasn‚Äôt helped; rather than prioritising core fixes and stability, they continued their usual DLC-driven model, pushing expansions while the foundational experience remained deeply flawed. For many players, it felt like the business decisions were being made at the expense of the game‚Äôs actual quality.

The slow development of essential tools further underscores the mismanagement. The long-awaited asset editor‚Äîfundamental for a city-building game whose community thrives on modding‚Äîis only expected to arrive by the end of the year. The fact that such a critical feature has taken two full years to materialise is, quite frankly, unacceptable for a sequel in a franchise that owes much of its longevity to user-generated content.

Looking ahead, Cities: Skylines II and its new development direction need to focus on bringing the game up to the standard set by Cities: Skylines 1. That means not only expanding content and deepening gameplay systems, but also delivering the optimisation required to handle large, complex cities. A modern city-builder shouldn‚Äôt start struggle when populations exceed 100,000 citizens, yet preformance and stability remains a persistent issue.

Ultimately, the future of Cities: Skylines II depends on whether the new team‚Äîand its publisher‚Äîcan recognise the game‚Äôs shortcomings, stabilise its performance, expand its content meaningfully, and rebuild real genuine trust with the community. For now, all we can do is wait and see if they can turn the game into the benchmark city-builder it was meant to be.

Cities Skylines II is nevertheless stunning, and now runs relatively smoothly for larger cities. There is no context in which I would recommend Cities Skylines I over the sequel, albeit if you have a ten year old computer. This is without question now the better game.

I played this game on free weekend.

And find it hard to give a definitive answer on this one.

Unlocking stuff is "kind of interesting", it felt like I was achieving something, that was a nice touch. Not sure if I am totally sold. But it it adds options to how you enjoy the game.

Love the bridges, they are not life changing, but having functional bridges is really cool.

I like the whole electricity balancing, it is another level of things you can do and I like playing around with it.

New info views that explain water, power and goods import and exports are a big improvement, I would like to see some better ones on some of these individual buildings. The static text data is here, but for a power plant for example. How big percentage of total production does it doe, how does it perform over the day and maybe some better explaining how the batteries work. I was just assuming the batteries would drain as soon as demand goes beyond production, but it is apparently a thing that only triggers during emergencies?

Some traffic things felt new, but after fiddling around with it for longer it does feel similar enough and easy enough to get used to the new quirks, traffic is not brainless and the same tricks I used to employ still work. So there is definitely something there.

In general, I am positive.

It runs just good enough to not make me Nauseous, and I mean that seriously, throwing around the camera, gives me a lurch and strain on my eyes and the smoother the camera movement, easier it is for me to digest. This game is not perfectly optimized and even at the current level of fidelity doesn't run super smoothly. And... that is ok enough, I thought it would be super important, but... it is good enough.

I keep coming back to... I want more, want it to be better, but this game is SOO CLOSE.

For a price I am willing to buy this and give it the benefit of the doubt.

What to say... what to write... well, let's begin with a basic question that most may have...

"Is the game functioning, playable, of working order?" 
To this I say, yes. Yes, this game manages to deliver most of what it has promised, from a diverse and intricate level of networks baked into every asset, of the game, to highly detailed rendering of.. sims, oddly enough. Although the game itself, although rough, and requiring some polish, (even after 2 years) manages to deliver a city-builder game unparalleled by any other, it stills fails to reckon with itself to bring detail and true inversion for the end user and player. The networks previously mentioned, although seemingly developed and... present, lack in true nuance, and unfortunately to not take all factors into account with regards to resources and availability. The realism of the game, therefore, is lacking. Although sims go about their daily life in eager bliss, it seems that every day, practically, around half, if not more, of all sims take the day off, or, spend the day shopping, unable to rally themselves to complete an honest days work. It leaves yourself wondering how businesses are able and capable of upholding themselves during such periods of workforce lull! Apologies for the tangent, but the realism is therefore, lacking.

I find that bugs are prevailing as well, in fact, I took a year long hiatus from the game due to a bug present within my hustling bustling city names Ugatis, bless the cities soul, for the postal system managed to become all topsie-turvey due to the establishment of a postage distribution center, not accepting nor distributing any postage, instead halting all postal operations citywide, leading to my sims happiness decreasing by scores. Updates are the arch-nemesis of the game, and, although beneficial, mostly, they may only detriment, or wholeheartedly uplift the game to higher degrees, it's a game of chance, honestly.

One final point, before my tone shifts for the better. development has just been thrown a wrench. Colossal Order, the corporation responsible for the development of the game, has just been removed from participating, continuing, on the game we so love. Cities Skylines (the first) was a legendary game, which was a solid pickup on sale. Sure, there was a lot of DLC, but the game was good enough on its own to hold its ground. Add a mix of mods in and there is a long lasting game. Cities Skylines 2 however, is simply OK. There are some wonky bugs found in the game, then on the flip side, there are additions to the game. To be honest I want to like it, but it feels like there's no real appeal to this one. 

The [b]gameplay[/b] is okay. The building scheme is not as flexible as the first. CS2 does try to keep that flexibility but the snapping is slightly odd. The camera [b]controls[/b] are all fine and dandy, but the visuals sometimes play some funky tricks depending on how the viewscreen (or camera) is moving. The game progression itself is fine and similar to the first (you know, turn down the services, crank the taxes until they complain, etc...). There is a challenge to it still managing a city, budget, and happiness, though sometimes a little mundane. The small little additions (which feels like the mod community made some serious additions that the first should've had) do give encouraging hope that the game is really trying to be a solid successor. There is more to manage and the city does feel like it is more impacted by real life events. The wind blows in a certain direction - directing smog. Natural disasters can occur. Supply of goods (such as electricity) can be traded. These are all welcomed additions to the game - that again - feel like should've been included in the first. However sour I am about it, I am still glad it was included in CS2. 

The [b]graphics and visuals[/b] make a solid attempt to be more realistic than the first. At that expense, it seems the game's stability has suffered a bit. The game at times can certainly look stunning, then move the camera a bit and the screen looks like its seizing up. Maybe its an effect? Maybe its just part of the game, who knows? Regardless, the effort is there to make the city a little more immersive (and fun to watch) than the first. The [b]sounds and music[/b] are a lot better in this one. A lot more can be heard, the music is nice and soothing, and again, an effort was made to immerse the player further into the game. Although the effort was made, it still does fall short from really hitting home. 

So why the negative review? I can't buy it being sold at the price its being asked. I can't see myself even getting it for a sale for 25% off. The game has been broken since launch for two years, and today the developer Colossal Order announced that they are abandoning the game, and handing it over to a company that exclusively works in mobile shovelware. The game, and franchise, is dead.

A Glimpse of the Future, Running on Hardware from the Future

Review:

There is a fine line between "ambitious" and "hubristic," and Cities: Skylines II has built a beautiful, eight-lane superhighway directly over that line... which promptly leads to a 15-frame-per-second traffic jam.

As the heir apparent to the undisputed champion of modern city-builders, CS:II had one job: to be CS:I but bigger, deeper, and better. It is, unequivocally, bigger. The "deeper" and "better" parts, however, seem tobe stuck in simulation-limbo, still waiting for a patch to load.

The Performance: A PowerPoint Presentation with Good Intentions
Let's address the elephant in the room‚Äîan elephant so large it has tanked the entire city's performance. This game is not "unoptimized" in the way we've come to expect. It is a work of technical audacity. It seems to believe that every player is running a dual-CPU quantum supercomputer cooled by liquid nitrogen.

My rig, which can comfortably render parallel universes in other AAA titles, sputters, chokes, and begs for mercy at the mere sight of a medium-sized suburb. We were promised a deep simulation; what we received is the world's most demanding slideshow. The game is meticulously simulating the dental records of every citizen, the thread count of their bedsheets, and the existential dread of their cat, all while forgetting that the player needs to be able to move the camera smoothly.

The "Deep" Simulation: A Puddle Pretending to be an Ocean
The core promise was a revolutionary economic and citizen AI. We were told every "cim" would live a "full life." This, it turnses out, is technically true. They are born, they get a job (which they may or may not drive to), they mysteriously generate wealth despite the entire city's economy being on fire, and then they require a hearse... which may or may not arrive before the next ice age.

The economy is a baffling magic show. Industries demand workers, but no one wants to work. You import... something... and export... something else... and your bank account either swells to the size of a small nation's GDP or collapses instantly. It's less "complex economic simulation" and more "pulling a lever on a very confusing slot machine." And the new land value mechanic? A fantastic way to ensure your entire population becomes homeless millionaires overnight.

The Foundation Is Here (The Rest Is Sold Separately)
Make no mistake, the bones of a masterpiece are here. The new road tools are (mostly) a dream. The scale is breathtaking. The potential for creation is vast.

But that's the key word: potential.

This feels like a game built for its next five years of DLC. So many features that were refined to perfection in the original‚Äîadvanced transit management, specific industry controls, even basic landscaping props‚Äîare either missing, broken, or simplified to the point of being abstract art. It's a magnificent, sprawling, half-empty canvas.

The Verdict:

Cities: Skylines II is not a bad game. It is a fantastic game that is trapped inside an unfinished, unoptimized, and frankly, baffling piece of software. It is a blueprint for a 10/10 sequel that was shipped as a 5/10 reality.

It has successfully captured the feeling of being a real-life city mayor: you have grand, beautiful plans, but you're constantly fighting a broken infrastructure, a nonsensical budget, and a population that seems to be operating on a different plane of existence.

It‚Äôs an investment in a future promise, not a finished product. We were sold a metropolis; we received a construction site with a fantastic parking lot.

Iv'e put a couple of hundred hours into the game and after finally getting what I paid for 2 years after launch, I hate to write this review. This game has been an roller coaster of emotions. I like the base game and it does show potential, but two years later the base problems still show.

NEGITIVES-
1. The performance issues are still here after two full years. Currently my system has issues playing when cities start to get larger. I play with a pretty new system: Ryzen 9 9500x3D / 64GB DRR5 / 3090 (I've also tried it with a 5080) and the game still struggles. I can't picture what the performance issues are like with people who run this game on less powerful hardware. It really makes this game less accessible for most people which is what made Cities 1 great.

2. The lack of content/communication with the overall player base is pretty disappointing. I've tried to give the devs a overall pass on it, but I'm really just getting sick of the lack of communication. Not just on Steam, but all their social media platforms. Its not easy to really know what is going on with the game unless you are in the know.

3. The Paradox Mod launcher is a joke. The Paradox Mod launcher is semi functional half the time and refuses to load some texture on OFFICIAL PACKS they decided to launch in the mod launcher instead of just launching it from the Steam Store as a free dlc. (Personal opinion, I believe they done this to make it easier on the eventual console release. However if they can't get this game running on current hardware, idk how they will attempted to do it on already 5 year old consoles) I want to defend this launcher cause it will be nice for console player to have access to mods, but at this point they should have just gave us access to the Steam Workshop at this point instead of this forever beta launcher.

4. Bugs bugs and more bugs. The amount of bug that linger in this game after two years is almost incredible. Currently idk if the homeless bug is still in the game, but I am pretty sure it's there. If I went through a describe every single bug in the current build, this review would be massive. Its gotten so bad, I honestly don't know if the info the game gives me is correct. How can I fix something with my city if the game is giving me incorrect or inaccurate info.

5. Lack of content. After two years we finally get our first major DLC Bridges and Ports. While this DLC adds a lot of content, we are still miles away from what Cities Skylines was during the first two years. While they have been trying to improve on adding more content, its going to be a while before we see anything. Its been two year and we still don't have bikes in the base game. While the dev's said they have been working on it I personally believe we are still a while off from bikes being added to the game, maybe in 2026.(I know they said late 2025, but I can't trust them anymore on that promise with the amount of delays). Another thing I just thought of is why are districts less detailed in their policies over Cities 1? We did get a lot of policies from DLC but we still got a lot for the base game. Hell I have more fingers on my hands than policies in this game.


Positives-
1.Road building tool is nice compared to Cities 1. While this can be fixed with mods in Cities Skylines, I personally don't like playing with mods and I want to keep things as vanilla as possible. 

2. The overall style they went with in this game is nice compared to the more ruff style of Cities 1. Its got a mix of Sim City design combined with a more grounded look and I personally like it.

3. The amount of zoning styles are good and provide players a good amount of options for how they would like to build. 

4. The increase map size is a huge plus for allowing mega sprawl. Cities Skylines was pretty limited on the size of its map and the limit they imposed on how many tiles you can own and this became a larger problem later on when DLC got larger. 

Overall I'm going to keep a eye on the game and see how it improves over time, but for know I think I will limit myself on this game and avoid buying any DLC till they fix performance and the lack of base content for start. If you want to play a good city builder. I would advise picking up Cities Skylines and all of its DLC's over the past 10 year at a discount when they are on sale. 

I do want to make my self clear about my personal opinion of the dev's, I know they are trying their best to make this game what they wish it could have been and I wish them all the best in that regard. If anyone is to blame for this game being the way it is, its Paradox Interactive. I've been playing Paradox games since 2013 and they started to go downhill back from 2019-2020, while they are trying to improve they are  still reason why this game launched the way it did. 

As a side note: When this game did launch it did make Paradox reevaluate other games before they launch. Prison Architect 2 is the best example of this and If you are interested in that, I would recommend checking it out.


Overall I give Cities Skylines 2 a 4/10. The only time I would buy this game at its current state is doing a Steam Sale for 70% off

They outsourced many systems, and most of those systems released with the game in a terrible state or not at all. Unity in particular failed to deliver tools CO was going to use to build the Asset Editor, which led to what will be a nearly 2 year delay before we will even see a beta version. 

CS2 released in a state that was poorly optimized in general, but has seen some improvements. You definitely still need a powerful PC to run this, and an even better one to build a city beyond 250k pop. 

As of writing this, news just broke that CO is handing development over to Iceflake Studios, a small PDX developer with a portfolio consisting of mobile slop. This is not promising, and is likely PDX moving the game onto life-support. It's likely that some of CO will stay on to help onboard the new studio for at least a little while, or even move to Iceflake. Iceflake currently has several core development team positions open, including one titled "GAME DESIGNER" to work on citybuilder and management games, with a deep understanding of management game mechanics and knack for balancing game economies and simulations. They're also looking for people to fill a position called "SIMULATION PROGRAMMER." These job openings tell me they currently don't have the needed specialist game devs to work on CS2.

As for the game itself, The vision was grand, the improvements to tools and updated visuals were promising. The content came very late. Free content creator packs kept it going for a while until they delivered the first major dlc 2 years late. Modders did what they could to get it into a playable state, but the lack of asset editor crippled the community. There's currently a crippling traffic bug that causes Cims to visit commercial properties at an insane rate, leading to intense traffic. The economy and jobs are not consistent, indicating bugs.

Only get this game if you want to take a risk on the new studio in the coming years, or have faith that modders and content creators will fix the game enough and provide enough new buildings without having to fight hard against whatever updates the new devs might push.
